section-block.rac_essential-question: What can happen when we try something new?

section-block.rac_book_summary: Jabari has finished his swim lessons and is ready to take a daring plunge—from the high diving board! But as he looks up, up, up at the board, he begins to think maybe he’s NOT so ready. Will Jabari jump?

section-block.rac_copyright_line: 978-1-338-65524-7. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Jabari Jumps by Gaia Cornwall. Copyright © 2017 by Gaia Cornwall. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Candlewick Press. Clifford the Big Red DogTM illustration copyright © The Norman Bridwell Trust.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: READY, SET, GO | WEEK 2: Try It!

section-block.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Use Yy, Vv, and Qq Alphabet Cards.
section-block.rac_body-text: Tell children that today we will review the letters Yy, Vv, and Qq.
Explain that in this book, the main character is a good jumper. Then, invite children to jump on both feet, one foot, back and forth, and so on.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read a narrative called Jabari Jumps by Gaia Cornwall.
Pablo can see this narrative is about facing our fears. Pablo can think of other narratives about facing fears! Can you?
While we read, I have a question I want you to think about. When we’re done reading, we will try to answer it together. Ready?
How does Jabari feel before he jumps off the diving board?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Listen to the title of this narrative: Jabari Jumps. What matching sound is at the beginning of both of these words?
Jabari is ready to jump off the diving board! How do you think Jabari feels about jumping?
Jabari is letting children take a turn jumping before him. Why do you think he is doing this?
Jabari says he is tired. Do you think Jabari is tired? What do you think Jabari is feeling?
Jabari’s dad tells Jabari it’s okay to be scared. Think of a time when you were scared. What did you do? How did you feel?
This picture shows what Jabari sees from the edge of the diving board.
Describe what Jabari sees.
Jabari jumped! How do you think he feels now?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
How does Jabari feel before he jumps off the diving board?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, choose two or three children to share their responses.
Possible responses:
Write and read aloud short sentences giving your opinion about Jabari’s bravery.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How did Jabari’s dad know that Jabari was scared?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: By having children connect what they’ve read to other texts, they will deepen their understanding of this story. Introduce other texts that teach the same lesson. Some suggestions include Brave Little Monster, Lionheart, and I’m Not Scared. As you do, model making connections to similarities in character, plot, or other story elements.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: READY, SET, GO | WEEK 2: Try It!

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Understand Abilities
section-block.rac_body-text: Tell children that sometimes it’s important for us to know what we’re good at and what might scare us. Share a time when you were scared to do something. When you realized what you could do, you were able to face your fears. Ask children to share a time when they were scared. Ask them what made them feel better and how they were able to face their fear.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread Jabari Jumps by Gaia Cornwall. This time, let’s talk about how Jabari faced his fear.

Clifford knows he would be scared to jump off a diving board that high—even though he’s big! But he also knows he’s a good swimmer. He wonders if this narrative can teach him how not to be scared, too!

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Why does Jabari think he is ready to jump off the diving board? (MB)
Do you believe Jabari when he says he’s not scared? Why? Why not? (MB)
Listen to these two words: long ladder. What sound is at the beginning of both of these words? What letter makes that sound?
Jabari starts to climb up the ladder. Does Jabari think the ladder is too tall? (MB)
What reasons does Jabari give for not jumping? Do you think he really needs to stretch? (MB)
What does Jabari’s dad tell him about being scared? Why is it okay to be scared? (MB)
Jabari thinks he is ready to jump now. Do you think he is really ready this time? What changed? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Give children crayons and paper. Ask them to draw something they can draw well. Then, ask them to try to draw something they would like to learn to draw better.
Say to children: Share your opinion. What does Jabari think he’s good at? Transcribe their speech as they take turns answering. Then read back their responses.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Reading is one of the best ways kids can learn about their own abilities and limitations. Children can practice understanding their own feelings. This initial learning about self will develop into accepting responsibility for their actions and reactions. It can guide children to make better or different decisions in the future. (Parenttoolkit.com/Self-awareness)

section-block.rac_top-left_header: READY, SET, GO | WEEK 2: Try It!

section-block.rac_body-text: Explain that we can connect the events in Jabari Jumps to something that happened in our own lives.
Challenge children to picture themselves as Jabari. Have them imagine the water beneath the diving board. Tell them to get into a steady stance and . . . jump!.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to revisit the book Jabari Jumps by Gaia Cornwall.
Pablo is excited to reread the narrative. This time, he is going to look very carefully at the details so he can retell the story.
Keep in mind this question as we reread today:
How do we know Jabari is scared of jumping off the diving board?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 3 prompts. Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to answer questions. Have back-and-forth conversations with children as they make connections to literature.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Why do you think the children spread their arms before they jump?
Have you ever spread your arms and jumped?
What do you think Jabari is thinking as he’s looking up the ladder?
Why is it important to stretch before you exercise? What kinds of stretches is Jabari doing? Show me how you can stretch!
Why do you think Jabari wants to jump off the diving board tomorrow instead of today?
Why does Jabari whisper that he loves surprises right before he jumps?
Listen to these two words: water with. What matching sound is at the beginning of both of these words? What letter makes that sound?
Did you think about the question while we reread our book?
How do we know Jabari is scared of jumping off the diving board?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, choose two or three children to share their answers.
Possible answers:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Jabari lets kids go before him in line.

section.rac_body-text: Work together with children to describe Jabari. Encourage children to use descriptive words and help them write the words.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Does Jabari let kids go before him?
Jabari lets kids go b_______ (before) him in line.
Jabari lets kids go before him in line.
How do you think Jabari would have felt if he hadn’t jumped?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Retelling stories is a great strategy for reading comprehension for multilingual learners. It helps children focus on main ideas, notice details, and follow the sequence of events that makes up the plot. Invite children to retell the story and allow multilingual learners to renact parts of the story to aid in comprehension.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: READY, SET, GO | WEEK 2: Try It!

section-block.rac_body-text: Remind children that everyone has things they find difficult. Persistence and approaching problems in new ways can help children reach their goals.
Jabari jumps and this boy races. Invite children to act out a common action word like swim, skip, walk, dance, twirl, or stretch. Have their partner guess the action.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read a poster called I Like to Race. It is a narrative about a boy who takes part in a really cool race!
Pablo loves to race! He can’t wait to read about this race.
In both Jabari Jumps and I Like to Race, two boys work hard to accomplish something they weren’t sure they could do. Let’s see what else is the same about these two texts!
As we read the Big Chart, let’s talk about the concept question for the week:
What can happen when we try something new?

section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to answer.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What does the boy do to get ready? What could happen if he didn’t stretch?
What kinds of stretches does Jabari do? Are they the same as the boy in the poster?
Why is it important to ask adults for help? What tips does the boy get? Does Jabari get any tips?
What is the boy wearing to stay safe during his race? What does Jabari’s sister wear to stay safe in the water?
The boy likes to race fast!

section.rac_body-text: Have children keep working to achieve a harder goal. For example, challenge them to write each letter in their name, then to write them all together to spell out their names. When they’ve completed the task, compliment their efforts, drawing attention to persistence and asking for help when necessary.
Provide a writing prompt about how the racer and Jabari are alike, and give ongoing feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt. Allow children to share their responses.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: At this stage of development, children may not know how to regard people with physical differences, and may have questions. Set aside time to answer them. You have the opportunity to dispel myths about peers with disabilities and teach children that all people have many things in common.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: READY, SET, GO | WEEK 2: Try It!

section-block.rac_body-text: Have children practice acting out different parts of the book, such as climbing the ladder, stretching, standing at the edge of the diving board, jumping off the diving board with their arms spread wide, and swimming in a pool.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to retell and reenact the book Jabari Jumps by Gaia Cornwall, and share how that story is like things that happen in our own lives.
Pablo loves this narrative because he can think of a lot of ways it is just like his real life.
You’ve had time to think about this book, and we’re going to share some of your thoughts today. As we reread it, keep in mind your answers to this question:
How are you like Jabari?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the book together. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to actively participate in the prompts below.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Think of a time you decided to try something new and were a little scared. What was it? (MB)
Listen to these two words: dove down. What matching sound is at the beginning of both of these words? What letter makes that sound?
Let’s look up the ladder. Now let’s pretend to let other kids go before us in line. After you! I insist!
Let’s climb up the ladder! Now let’s climb down the ladder and practice our stretches!
Jabari’s dad tells him what he does when he is afraid. How do you calm yourself when you are scared?
Let’s take a deep breath just like Jabari does. Ready? Show me how you inhale and exhale!
Jabari faced his fear! Can you think of a time when you faced your fear? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Give children a moment to Turn and Talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How are you like Jabari?
section.rac_body-text: Then, choose two or three children to share their ideas.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: I don’t give up when I’m scared.
I have tried a scary thing!

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write about one scary thing they tried and found they really liked.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What is one thing you tried that you were scared to do? Did you feel the same way Jabari did?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Sharing their stories will help boost self-esteem in children. It will also provide children with the mental association between trying new things and receiving praise for their efforts. Share your own childhood stories—of success and failures. Sharing will help children feel how important they are to you.
